title: Inductor - energy of inductors of different length

content.question: Solenoid <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is made of a coil of wire of resistivity <math alttext="rho" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ρ</mi></math>. The two ends of the solenoid are connected to a battery of <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> <math alttext="open E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>. When there is a steady current in the solenoid, the magnetic field stores energy <math alttext="U sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. Solenoid <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is made of the same type of wire, has the same number of coils per unit length, and has the same cross-sectional area as Solenoid <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Solenoid <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is twice the length of Solenoid <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Solenoid <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is disconnected from the battery and Solenoid <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is connected to the same battery. How much energy is stored in Solenoid <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> when there is a steady current in Solenoid <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>?
